statement.text: The Wells Score is a clinical prediction rule used to estimate the pretest probability of DVT, guiding whether to proceed with D-dimer testing or imaging. Points are assigned for clinical features (leg swelling, tenderness, immobilization, prior DVT, malignancy, alternative diagnosis less likely). Score ≥2 = DVT likely (ultrasound indicated); Score <2 = DVT unlikely (D-dimer first).
statement.formal: Wells DVT Score: Sum of points from 9 criteria | Score <2 = DVT Unlikely (NPV 95% if D-dimer negative) → D-dimer first | Score ≥2 = DVT Likely (prevalence 30-50%) → Ultrasound

explanation.intuition: Not everyone with leg pain has a DVT. The Wells Score is a checklist that helps estimate how likely a DVT is before doing any tests. It counts up risk factors (recent surgery, cancer, swelling) and subtracts points if there's an obvious alternative explanation. Low-risk patients can avoid ultrasound if their D-dimer is negative. High-risk patients need ultrasound regardless of D-dimer.
explanation.key_insight: The Wells Score combined with D-dimer testing allows safe exclusion of DVT without imaging in about 30-50% of suspected cases. This 'two-step' approach - score first, then D-dimer if low risk - is more cost-effective and reduces unnecessary ultrasounds. The key is using the score to guide the diagnostic pathway, not to make the diagnosis itself.
explanation.technical_details: Original Wells criteria include 9 items: (1) Active cancer (+1); (2) Paralysis/immobilization (+1); (3) Bedridden >3 days or surgery <12 weeks (+1); (4) Tenderness along deep veins (+1); (5) Entire leg swollen (+1); (6) Calf swelling >3cm compared to other side (+1); (7) Pitting edema (+1); (8) Collateral superficial veins (+1); (9) Prior documented DVT (+1); (10) Alternative diagnosis as likely or more likely (-2). Score interpretation: <2 = DVT unlikely (prevalence 5-15%), ≥2 = DVT likely (prevalence 25-45%). In DVT unlikely group: negative D-dimer safely excludes DVT (sensitivity ~99%). In DVT likely group: proceed directly to ultrasound.
common_misconceptions: Wells Score diagnoses DVT - it estimates probability to guide testing
Low Wells Score means no DVT - low probability isn't zero, D-dimer still needed
D-dimer works for everyone - only useful in 'DVT unlikely' group
High D-dimer means DVT - D-dimer is sensitive but not specific

definitions_glossary.pretest_probability: Likelihood of disease before diagnostic testing
definitions_glossary.clinical_prediction_rule: Algorithm using clinical features to estimate disease probability
definitions_glossary.d_dimer: Blood test for fibrin degradation products, elevated in clot
definitions_glossary.negative_predictive_value: Probability that negative test truly excludes disease
definitions_glossary.sensitivity: Proportion of diseased individuals correctly identified as positive

wells_criteria.criterion: Active cancer (treatment within 6 months or palliative)
Paralysis, paresis, or recent leg cast immobilization
Bedridden >3 days or major surgery <12 weeks requiring GA/regional
Localized tenderness along distribution of deep venous system
Calf swelling >3 cm compared to asymptomatic leg (measured 10 cm below tibial tuberosity)
Pitting edema confined to symptomatic leg
Alternative diagnosis at least as likely as DVT

dvt_likely.note: D-dimer not useful as first test

diagnostic_algorithm: If D-dimer positive OR Wells ≥2: Order ultrasound
If ultrasound negative and high suspicion: Repeat in 5-7 days or consider CT/MR venography

definition.@value: Clinical prediction rule to estimate pretest probability of DVT and guide diagnostic testing

sources.citation: Wells PS, et al. Value of assessment of pretest probability of deep-vein thrombosis in clinical management. Lancet. 1997;350:1795-1798.
Wells PS, et al. Ann Intern Med. 2003;138:864-870.

learning_objectives: List the components of the Wells Score for DVT
Calculate and interpret the Wells Score
Apply the score to guide diagnostic testing
Understand the role of D-dimer in low-probability patients
clinical_pearls: Alternative diagnosis as likely = -2 points (important for specificity)
Low Wells + negative D-dimer = DVT safely excluded
High Wells = go straight to ultrasound, skip D-dimer
D-dimer is sensitive but not specific - many false positives
